abstract.p: Avoiding interference of seal pair in triple-offset butterfly valve is critical to its performance and service time. In this article, a mathematical model is proposed for the seal interface. A formula is derived to evaluate the interference of seal pair in triple-offset butterfly valve. Five parameters are considered, including the diameter of valve disc, the effective sealing thickness, axial offset, radial offset, and eccentric angle. The influences of axial offset, radial offset, and eccentric angle on the interference area and position are investigated. The results show that the interference area decreases initially and increases finally when either the axial offset or the eccentric angle increases, whereas it decreases monotonously as the radial offset increases.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Featured as special triple-offset structure, triple-offset butterfly valve (TOBV) possesses many advantages. For example, the seal surfaces of the valve and the seat can be separated instantly during the disengagement; therefore, no extra friction will be resulted in. Excellent sealing with minimal friction can be achieved, and the service time of the valve can be prolonged. The sealing performance can also be improved. Under the same external torque for closing, TOBV exhibits better sealing property than conventional valves. In addition, TOBV can sustain larger pressure drop than other types of butterfly valve. All these characteristics have ensured its acceptance in a variety of applications covering a wide range of industries that include water treatment, petrochemical, oil and gas processing, aerospace, offshore platform, marine, etc. and the demand for it, remains buoyant as ever.1

Comparing with conventional butterfly valves, TOBV presents a more complex structure, which requires a higher standard for design. Unsuccessful design usually results in leakage and interference at the seal interface,2,3 thus compromising the performance and service time of the valve. When designing the geometrical structure of butterfly valves, determining appropriate parameters is the key task. There have been several discussions carried out on this topic.4–7 For example, Xu and Wang4 analyzed the sealing-contact problem of TOBV using finite element method and obtained the contact pressure distribution on the sealing surface. Ding et al.5 carried out optimization design for zero-friction requirement in closing/opening actions of TOBV. Taking both flow characteristic and structural safety into consideration, Song et al.6,7 proposed models for multidisciplinary optimization of traditional butterfly valve. However, a mathematical formula for the evaluation of interference of seal pair in TOBV has not been proposed. Moreover, the influences of three offset parameters on the interference have not been clearly understood.

In this article, a formula for the evaluation of interference of seal pair in TOBV is derived by establishing a mathematical model for the seal interface. The interrelationship between the design parameters including the three offsets, namely axial offset, radial offset, and eccentric angle, are described. Based on the model, discussions are carried out in order to point out how the three offsets affect the sealing property.

sec.title: Mathematical model for the seal interface
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the structure of a TOBV, which includes the valve disc, valve seat, and the drive trunnion. The three offsets of the TOBV are (1) axial offset c, which is the offset from the rotary axial center to the center plane of the valve disc; (2) radial offset e, which is the offset from the rotary axial center to the center line of the valve disc; (3) eccentric angle β , which is the angle between the center line of conic sealing surface and the center line of the valve disc. The effective sealing thickness is noted as t. Figure 1.

The Cartesian coordinate system is established by taking the apex of the cone sealing surface as origin. The x-axis is defined to be perpendicular to the valve plane, whereas the y-axis parallels the plane of the valve disc (Figure 2). sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows how the interference area changes as the axial offset c and the radial offset e vary when Dmax = 250 mm, t = 14 mm, and β = 13°. In the figure, z0 denotes the distance in z-direction from the points on the interface to the axis of the valve seat. From the values of Dmax, t, and β , it can be determined that for z0 < 119.96 mm, two hyperbolic segments are obtained as the plane z = z0 truncated the conic sealing surface, whereas for 119.96 mm < z0 < 121.62 mm (here, z0 < 121.62 mm is the condition for that the plane |z| = z0 and the disc plane have intersection line), only one hyperbolic segment is obtained. In Figure 4, black area indicates non-interference, whereas white area indicates interference. Figure 4.
The changes of interference (in white color) and non-interference (in black color) areas as the axial offset c varies; c = (a) 10 mm; (b) 20 mm; (c) 25 mm; (d) 30 mm; (e) 35 mm; (f) 45 mm; (g) 50 mm; (h) 60 mm; and (i) 80 mm.

From Figure 4(a), it can be seen that for c = 10 mm, the interference area decreases as e increases. When e < 20 mm, the interference areas present at the locations of high z0, while the non-interference area is observed at the locations of low z0. With the increase of e, the interference area shrinks, while the non-interference area expands. When e > 60 mm, the non-interference for the entire sealing surface can be achieved.

In Figure 4(b) to (d), the distribution of interference and non-interference areas is similar to that in Figure 4(a). However, as c increases from 10 to 30 mm, the interference area decreases, especially when e is relatively small. In addition, the value of e for non-interference for the entire sealing surface decreases from 60 mm in Figure 4(a) to 4.7 mm in Figure 4(d).

On the other hand, Figure 4(d) to (i) indicate that increasing c does not necessarily lead to the decrease of interference area. In fact, when e is relatively small (i.e. 10 mm for Figure 4), the interference area increases gradually from 4.7 mm in Figure 4(d) to the maximum (interference for the entire sealing surface) in Figure 4(i) as c increases from 30 to 80 mm. Moreover, the value of e for non-interference for the entire sealing surface increases with the increasing c, from 4.7 mm (Figure 4(d)) to 62 mm (Figure 4(i)).

Figure 4 also indicates that for a given c, non-interference for the entire sealing surface can be achieved by increasing e. However, since larger e results in larger torque required for driving the valve disc, smaller e is desired in design. On the other hand, when e (usually a small value) is chosen, it is a key task to determine an appropriate value of c to minimize the interference area. From Figure 4, non-interference for the entire sealing surface may not be possible when e = 0. However, it can be achieved by increasing e for a small magnitude. For example, when e is increased to 8 mm, non-interference can be achieved as long as c is between 25 and 30 mm.

To investigate the influence of eccentric angle on the interference property, further study is carried out by varying the eccentric angle from 7° to 19°, while maintaining Dmax (250 mm), t (14 mm), and c (30 mm) the same. Figure 5 shows the results. From the figure, the optimal eccentric angle β is about 13° (Figure 5(c)) for the interference area is negligibly small even for small e value when β = 13°. As β decreases, the interference area increases. Dramatic changes are observed for e < 20 mm. When β = 7°, interference occurs at the entire sealing surface for any e value less than 26 mm. On the other hand, as β increases from 13° to 19°, the interference area increases as well, but with less magnitude compared with that when decreasing β . The results suggest that increasing β can reduce the interference area, but further increase of β leads to the increase of the interference area. Therefore, an optimal eccentric angle exits, i.e. it is about 13° when Dmax = 250 mm, t = 14 mm, and c = 30 mm. Figure 5.
The changes of interference (in white color) and non-interference (in black color) areas as the eccentric angle β varies. (a) 7°; (b) 10°; (c) 13°; (d) 16°; and (e) 19°.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A mathematical model has been proposed to study the interference of seal pair in TOBV. A formula for assessing the interference area has been derived. Calculation results based on the model show that the increase of either axial offset or eccentric angle can decrease the interference area before increasing it finally, whereas the increase of radial offset leads to the monotonous decrease of the interference area. The efforts made in this article may provide a clue for the optimal design of TOBV.
